awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies problems in spectral theory, the mathematical theory that describes physical notions such as energy levels of quantum systems and vibration frequencies of mechanical systems. The mathematical models considered are in regimes where there are competing influences from a disorder in the interaction and some long-range order, such as spatially slowly decaying interactions and quasi-periodic interactions. One focus is on applications of spectral theory to explain conservation laws in certain nonlinear systems and find otherwise hidden predictability in their behavior, described through the mathematical notion of integrability. The project focuses on Schrodinger operators, central to quantum mechanics, and the mathematical methods developed have the potential to illuminate other mathematical models and physical applications, such as electron conductivity in disordered materials and signal transmission using solitons. 

One main focus of this project is the spectral theory of almost periodic Schrodinger operators and integrability of the Korteweg-de Vries equation with almost periodic initial data. While a Lax pair representation formally rewrites the equation as an isospectral flow, rigorous characterizations of integrability, such as construction of an inverse scattering transform, are highly dependent on the phase space under consideration and require and motivate deep new results in direct and inverse spectral theory. Other topics considered in this project include estimates for the size and continuity of the solution in terms of spectral data, Schrodinger operators with slowly decaying potentials, higher-order Szego theorems, and transport properties of Schrodinger operators and quantum spin systems.

por.por_cntn:
This is a project in the spectral theory of Schrodinger operators - differential expressions which describe the motion of particles in quantum mechanics. The mathematical theory focuses on their spectral properties, which often have a physical interpretation (for example, the spectrum is physically interpreted as the set of possible energies of the quantum particle, and finer properties of the spectrum influence the way in which the particle propagates through space), as well as inverse spectral theory, which investigates the reconstruction of an operator from its spectral properties. This project also studies mathematically related systems including Jacobi matrices, orthogonal polynomials, and canonical systems.

Inverse spectral theory is very dependent on properties of the spectrum, and was originally developed for sets with finitely many gaps. For so-called Widom sets (including infinite gap sets which are not "too sparse"), this project provides a general description of associated reflectionless canonical systems and almost periodicity of their coefficients, where all previous results required model-specific gap summability conditions at infinity.

This project develops a theory of Stahl-Totik regularity for Schrodinger and Dirac operators, which provides universal inequalities for the asymptotic behavior of eigensolutions and zero distributions; the cases when equality holds are said to be regular operators. One aspect of this work is a discovery of a new renormalized Robin constant in the two-term asymptotic expansion of a function associated with the spectrum; this renormalized Robin constant serves as a measure of the size of the spectrum and provides a criterion for regularity.

Many properties of a measure or operator are encoded by a Christoffel-Darboux kernel - a function generated by orthogonal polynomials or eigenfunctions. Bulk universality is a common phenomenon where a double scaling limit of the Christoffel-Darboux kernel converges to the sine kernel. This project generalizes previously known sufficient conditions for bulk universality and provides the first local criterion, which depends only on the behavior of the measure near the point of interest. In particular, it is shown that bulk universality holds almost everywhere with respect to the absolutely continuous part of the measure. This is done by a new approach which relies on the de Branges theory of canonical systems. This approach even provides some "if and only if" statements involving a matrix kernel, which contain subordinacy theory as a special case.
